title: What is the Netherlands famous for? - Quora

response.answer_text: [This is a list off the top of my head. Some things I like to hope we are known for.] Nederland, The Netherlands:17 million citizens on a small patch of land. A good 3 Hours drive from top to bottom. It also sorta looks like a toddlers rendition of a little man.  The obvious: Clogs:1 Klomp, 2 Klompen  Windmills:1 Windmolen, 2 Windmolens  Stroopwafels:1 Stroopwafel, 2 Stroopwafels  Bicycles:1 Fiets, 2 Fietsen  Thatched roofs:1 Rieten dak, 2 Rieten daken:  Now that’s out of the way; The not so obvious: Police:1 Motormuis, 2 Motormuizen:  (Social) Safety:  Often overlooked by us Dutch folk, cause it is never seen. Fairly often taken for granted, only felt when it is not there. This is probably one of the safest places on earth. With easy access to physical and mental healthcare. And a social safety net for when ‘life’ happens. Which supports you after losing your job and/or income, be it due to a reorganizing in the workplace or (mental) illness. They’re also there if you have difficulties in other areas of daily life like cleaning the house, taking care of yourself, or taking care of the rules. The countless, never ending rules. Which is a great segue to my next point. Bureaucracy:‘Muggenziften’ ‘Mierenneuken’ - Nitpicking, Splitting hairs (loosely translated)  We like to keep track of things. Lots and lots of things. We like rules. Lots and lots of little tiny little rules (‘regeltjes’).I like to reason it comes with the territory of the social safety net and people’s efforts to abuse it, but it’s likely far more complicated than that. It can be quite a maze to get things done over here. And it can be quite a wait too. Only to hear that your application has taken a detour at some department or other. Oh wait, it was just at the bottom of this pile. “Ah, yes I’m gonna need more information from you. If you can please fill out and send me these forms. Then we can start the application process. This can take up to 13 weeks.” Lifting and Moving big things:1 Mammoet, 2 Mammoeten(?)   How to take land from, and NOT slide back into, the sea:Remember, large portions of our country lies beneath sea level. Afsluitdijk  StormvloedkeringThose 2 white arms MOVE, to lock down one of the most important harbors into and out of Europe, in the event of a storm.  We do Flowers: “ [in 2013] The Netherlands still exports more than half of all the cut flowers globally ”[1] Bloemenveiling Aalsmeer  - Lots and lots of flowers: Bloemencorso - These are all made with friggin flowers. We do this every year. It’s a huge event, with countless of these cars/floats(?). It’s nuts.    Safety (continued) - Wildlife and nature in generalBig scary wolf:  Last year we had a wolf take a stroll around the “Drenthse” country-side for a few weeks. Which gave everybody a big scare:“A wild animal on our lands?” “It’s a danger to our cows and kids.” “It’s a menace to our traffic. It distresses drivers by walking next to the road. It makes drivers rubberneck, and causes accidents (on the ‘dodenweg’).” After a while it was shot and killed to prevent it from ‘becoming a problem’ basically. It got a statue though,:  - It’s near a parking space. I drive by it sometimes. Now we’ve spotted a pack of wolves near our border. The first in many years. Farmers are up in arms. Mothers fear for their children. Apart from that we don’t have scary wildlife around here. No huge spiders, ants or giant centipedes. Nor bears, tigers or hippos. No, we….. We fear ticks:  - And maybe the neighbors untrained / mistreated pet dog. The harshest of weather:  - Ankle high water in a valley. ‘Drouwen’ We get the occasional (yearly) local floods in some choice areas. And on the rare occasion a ‘small scale’ tornado graces us with it’s presence. Next to that, we have: the mandatory Yearly Heat Wave.Oh, and of course the autumn storms.And the week or 2 of ‘sudden’ frost (no one ever sees coming) where people become even bigger dangers to themselves.But no one really cares. We just bitch-and-moan a lot. For that is about all that nature throws at us. ===== Oh, we had a lenient policy on soft-drugs too before it was the cool thing to do, so we are hipsters in that too I guess. ===== Edit; Wow, This actually got upvotes and views. Thanks for reading my ramblings. Also Thanks for the input. I indeed forgot how Huge flowers are for us. Also added the ‘dangerous’ local wildlife. Footnotes[1] Top 10 cut flower exporters in the world

When you say famous things I think of two different things: Something Holland is known for (e.g. Famous Dutch people, famous traditions, famous brands, etc.) or some famous places in Holland. First I will start of with stating what Holland is. Holland is not the same as the country the Netherlands, which consists of more than just the two provinces of Holland (Noord- and Zuid-Holland). While Holland is the two provinces with the highest population, you can not just say Holland when you mean the Netherlands. I assume you meant the whole country the Netherlands when you said Holland, so I will answer this keeping that in mind. Some famous people from the Netherlands: Rembrandt van Rijn - Rembrandt Vincent van Gogh - Vincent van Gogh Antonie van Leeuwenhoek - Antonie van Leeuwenhoek Christiaan Huygens - Christiaan Huygens Hendrik Lorentz - Hendrik Lorentz Desiderius Erasmus - Erasmus Martin Garrix - Martin Garrix Armin van Buuren -Armin van Buuren Arjen Robben - Arjen Robben Johan Cruyff - Johan Cruyff Mata Hari - Mata Hari Some famous traditions: Sinterklaas - Sinterklaas Oliebollen - Oliebol Koningsdag - Koningsdag  Elfstedentocht - Elfstedentocht  Some famous Dutch brands: Shell - Royal Dutch Shell Heineken - Heineken Philips - Philips Other things the Netherlands is famous for: Liberal stand towards a lot of subjects (E.g. Weed, prostitution, LGBT) Tulips Cloggies (wooden shoes) Dutch cheese (Gouda, Edammer) Windmills Bicycles Well that were the famous Dutch things… Now some famous Dutch places: Amsterdam - AmsterdamWith a lot of the most famous museums, the ‘grachten’, the red light district and many more this is definitely the most famous place in the Netherlands.  Keukenhof - KeukenhofAfter Amsterdam this is probably the place where you will find the most tourists, this is often seen as “the most Dutch thing ever” (it is not).  Giethoorn - GiethoornOften said to be “The Venetia of the north”, in the summer there are more tourists than inhabitants in this place.  De afsluitdijk - AfsluitdijkOne of the most famous Dutch waterworks, this dyke successfully transformed the southern sea (de Zuiderzee) into the IJssellake (het IJsselmeer).  There is obviously a lot more than this. I will add more later and if you have suggestions, put them in the comments. All images are from Google and Wikipedia.

Ouf too many things here’s what comes to my mind right now but certainly more: AMSTERDAM is a startup hub with loads of cool companiesIt feeds the world second largest exporter of agriculture after USA. If you’re eating an onion odds are it comes from holland. It is an agricultural power house which uses very advanced and modern farming techniques (most advanced on earth in my opinion). Big thanks to Wageningen university for the great work and been a hugebpart of this!Water filtration and treatmentReclaiming farmable and buildable land from the sea. Chunks of the country are reclaimed from the sea!Very liberal countryThey invented the concept of shares of a companyVOCTradeOne of the largest ports in the world RotterdamHappy wealthy citizensIt’s below sea levelKlompen (Cloggs)Always ranked within the top 10 or top even 5 best countries to live in.

The Netherlands is one beautiful country and is known for many of her cultures and traditions. Some of which are; SkatingBicyclesFootballDredging and reclamationCheese makingClogsSinterklaas etc.But what she is truly famous for is her tulips.  Image: Google Search. The country is often called the "flower shop of the world" and both the locals and enthusiastic visitors are crazy about them! Despite tulips being introduced to the Netherlands in the 16th century, the craze for it hasn’t died down one bit till this day! There was even a tulip craze ‘Tulipmania’ between 1634 and 1637, where one tulip sold for more than a house in the most expensive neighbourhoods in Amsterdam! Today, tulips are still grown on huge flower fields full of rich colours. Every spring, millions of visitors come in to attend the various tulip festivals and also enjoy all that Keukenhof has to offer. If you want to see the beautiful tulip fields, don’t forget to visit next spring. Keukenhof is an unforgettable experience for people of all ages. The historic park with over 7 million flowering bulbs on a 32-hectare spacious land attracts millions of visitors to the Netherlands each year and next year, one of them could be you!

Read all the other answers. Some extra’s from History.Wall Street was built by the Dutch colonists in Nieuw Amsterdam (New York)The Declaration of Independence is based on the “Plakkaat van Verlaetinghe 1581. In this “plakkaat” the Dutch people declared their independence from Spain and established the Republiek van de Zeven Verenigde Provinciën of the Netherlands. The Constitution of the US is partially based on this Dutch republic.All over the world you find names of lands, islands, seas with Dutch namesBarents Sea named after Willem Barentszoon.Isla de los Estados Staten Island named after the Staten Generaal the first Dutch parliament The Island lies just East of the southern tip of South America.Cabo de Hornos the southern tip of South America named after the town Hoorn.New Zealand named after the province Zeeland.Tasmania. named after Abel TasmanArnhem land in Australia named after the city Arnhem. Kaap de Goede Hoop. South Africa. When this cape was spotted the sailors knew that they could turn east to their destination India or Indonesia. It is not the most southern tip of Africa that is Cape Agulhas.The Dutch supported the young USA against the UK. Smuggling weapons via the Dutch island St Eustatius.The legendary Rip van Winkle, known in New York State, Catskill Mountains, was a Dutchman.Several Presidents of the US had Dutch ancestry. Martin van Buuren, Theodore Roosevelt, Franklin D. Rosevelt.Up to 1850. The Dutch were the only foreigners permitted to trade with Japan via the harbour of Decima.

The Netherlands is known as being one of the most capable countries (if not the most) out there in the area of water management. From dredging (making canals, rivers deeper or even making new land from the sea, e.g. like the overpriced paradise islands in all sorts of shapes in the middle east's rich oil states)   It's also known for very good techniques and understanding of flood defense systems, flood barriers and levees like the maeslantkering as depicted below:  and the Westerscheldekering. These two are part of the much bigger "Delta plan" that has been executed in the last 50 years of the 20th century to keep the Netherlands safe.   And also lately an experiment to let nature help us to protect our sandy beaches and dunes by creating a "Sand engine" a.k.a. "Sand motor" that with some human sand replenishment efforts at the beginning, changes the flow of water to allow natural sand disposal on the beaches instead of sand distraction. We don't only keep our own feet dry, we help all over the world with work in this area from planning, design to execution.

What is famous about Holland? The flowers for one, especially the tulips. Dutch cheese, the Gouda you might know is originally a Dutch cheese now many times copied elsewhere. Best one still from The Netherlands Dutch beer - Heineken. Philips developed the CD and DVD, and is still the largest producer of light bulbs in the world. The well known liberal stance on things like soft drugs(illegal but allowed), prostitution (legal), gay marriage (first in the world) and mercy killing for terminally ill patients (allowed under regulation) even now for people who see their life as intolerable suffering. KLM, the oldest still existing airline in the world. We are famous for the water control innovations. Large part of the Netherlands is below sea level, but because of excellent dikes, dams and water control, we do not have wet feet, and actuallynare best prepared in the world for the potential rising of the seas due to global warming. These are a few things The Netherlands is famous for.

The Netherlands is a country famous for its canals and windmills, which constantly pump water out in the sea. so the country does not flood. The Dutch are always trying to steal land from the sea, which they do by first enclosing and drying sea areas and then adding dirt. Those man made areas are called polders. It is also famous for its dairy products, like butter and the well known cheeses from Edam and Gouda, the cities where these cheeses are produced. Also, the Netherlands is famous for its tulips, which were imported from Turkey in the XVIth century, but the Dutch found that their land was excellent for these flowers. Also famous is the Delft pottery, a pottery with windmills and seascapes, mainly in blue and white, originating in the City of Delft. And, we should also mention the Red Light District in Amsterdam and two of its famous painters, Vincent Van Gogh and Rembrandt.

Tulips Keukenhof - Wikipedia Keukenhof - Wikipedia Windmills Kinderdijk - Wikipedia Wooden clogs as traditional attire (farmers and gardeners stillnuse them) Volendam - Wikipedia And Red-light district - Wikipedia Coffeeshop (Netherlands) - Wikipedia In the Netherlands, coffeeshops are establishments where the sale of cannabis for personal consumption by the public is tolerated by the local authorities. And mayonaisse, we f*ckin' drown ’m in that shit:

In sport: Total Football (Totaal Voetbal) a style of football (soccer) that is predominantly attacking and where all players are competent enough to interchangeably play in different positions on the field, therefore maintaining a very fluid style of attacking play.  Although these days the Dutch national team does not really play this style well anymore.  But Holland still has lots of fans internationally because of their historical attacking and exciting football style. Holland is also famous for having the colour orange as their national colour and therefore their fans at international football events (or any sport for that matter) bring that joyous colour and attitude to the stadiums.

Rembrandt van Rijn Van Gogh Hugo Grotius Hugo Grotius - Wikipedia Windmills Clogs…. First country which issued shares First Stock exchange in the world Inventors of CD, WiFi, Bluetooth, Blu-ray and a lot morehttps://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&cd=12&ved=2ahUKEwj5w6rDruPcAhWvsqQKHbsuDCMQFjALegQIBhAB&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.expatica.com%2Fnl%2Fabout%2Fbest-inventions-dutch-inventions_1048952.html&usg=AOvVaw2wy1F-Rf8eZhfXsdn7hqG5 Freedom Happiest children in the world https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&cd=23&ved=2ahUKEwiC8KCbrePcAhVGa1AKHV6MBpwQFjAWegQIAxAB&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.marketwatch.com%2Fstory%2Fwhy-dutch-kids-are-the-happiest-in-the-world-2017-04-05&usg=AOvVaw0PFarGym9frDXUGWPI654Q El Dorado for cyclists Safe Well organized society

Flowers, cheese, the red light district, it's drug policy, clogs, tolerance and liberal state of mind) although not as tolerant as they like to claim)  and art (van gogh, vermeer etc), being the first country to legalize gay Marriage
Clogs.  Cheesse.  Weed.  Tulips and Heineken beer.  Windmills.   Herring.  Skating.  Clog dancing.
For one thing:For being a country that has a surface that for more than 50% is located below sea level, and which invests a *lot* of effort in staying dry, and is fairly successful at it, too.
The World Economic Forum just published a report saying that the Netherlands is the 2nd largest food exporter in the world, behind the US.
Cheese and tulips. When Russia invaded Ucraine Netherlands threatened not to send tulips to Russia any more. It seems the Russians felt seriously sanctioned.
